tags.title: Learning Objective
value: Explain the economic causes and effects of maritime exploration by the various European states.
Explain the process of state building and expansion among various empires and states in the period from 1450 to 1750.
Explain the continuities and changes in networks of exchange from 1450 to 1750.

tags.title: Thematic Focus
value: The development of ideas, beliefs, and religions illustrates how groups in society view themselves, and the interactions of societies and their beliefs often have political, social, and cultural implications.
As societies develop, they affect and are affected by the ways that they produce, exchange, and consume goods and services.

A variety of internal and external factors contribute to state formation, expansion, and decline. Governments maintain order through a variety of administrative institutions, policies, and procedures, and governments obtain, retain, and exercise power in

tags.title: Historical Development
value: Portuguese development of maritime technology and navigational skills led to increased travel to and trade with Africa and Asia and resulted in the construction of a global trading-post empire.
The Atlantic trading system involved the movement of goods, wealth, and labor, including enslaved people.

The new global circulation of goods was facilitated by chartered European monopoly companies and the global flow of silver, especially from Spanish colonies in the Americas, which was used to purchase Asian goods for the Atlantic markets and satisfy Chine

Europeans established new trading-posts in Africa and Asia, which proved profitable for the rulers and merchants involved in new global trade networks. Some Asian states sought to limit the disruptive economic and cultural effects of European dominated lo

The expansion of maritime trading networks fostered the growth of states in Africa, including the Asante and the Kingdom of the Kongo, whose participation in trading networks led to an increase in their influence.
